author: By New York Times Audio
title: Severe Weather in U.S., and Crisis in Ecuador
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Ancient Skeletons Give Clues to Modern Medical Mysteries
description: DNA fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into multiple sclerosis, diabetes, schizophrenia and other illnesses.
content: Multiple sclerosis, an autoimmune disease that affects 2.9 million people, presents a biological puzzle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh and Dani Blum
title: How to Make the Most of Your At-Home Covid Test
description: Here’s what you need to know about when to take a test for accurate results, and how to get kits for free.
content: While Covid has become a regular part of respiratory virus season, community testing centers and drive-through sites where you could determine whether it’s the source of your sniffles have all but vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Buds Go in Them
description: Chloe Revery and Alissa Revness divide and conquer.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘The Beekeeper’ Review: Sting Like a, You Know
description: In this action thriller, Jason Statham plays a man who will do whatever it takes to protect his hive.
content: “To bee or not to bee?” That is a question asked to Jason Statham in “The Beekeeper,” a delirious entry in the thriving genre of action flicks about gunslingers who list a different career on their LinkedIn. (See also: “The Painter” and “The Bricklayer,” both released just last week.) The director David Ayer’s previous shoot-em-up, “The Tax Collector,” was woefully short on quips about audits. He and the screenwriter Kurt Wimmer have not made that mistake here. Take a swig of mead every time Statham vows to protect the hive — by which he means society — and you’ll have a fine time. Either way, you won’t remember a thing about the plot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump’s Boldest Argument Yet: Immunity From Prosecution for Assassinations
description: A lawyer for the former president said he would be immune from prosecution for the murder of a political rival while in office unless he was first impeached and convicted in Congress.
content: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: A Super PAC Forms to Support No Labels
description: Officials with the group said they had $2 million in initial commitments but expect up to $300 million if there’s a “viable” ticket.
content: A political group intending to support a presidential candidate run by the group No Labels plans to file paperwork with the Federal Election Commission on Wednesday, with a handful of Republican and Democratic strategists as advisers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Genevieve Glatsky
title: Ecuadoreans Split on President’s Drastic New Measure to Combat Drug Gangs
description: Vowing to bring peace back to a shattered country, President Daniel Noboa has deployed the military to take on what he calls “terrorist” groups.
content: A sense of dread took hold in Ecuador on Wednesday, with the streets empty, schools closed and many people afraid to leave their homes after the disappearance of two gang leaders set off prison riots, police kidnappings and the on-air storming of a TV station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Secretary of Defense Can’t Go AWOL. Neither Can America.
description: If we turn our back on the world, there will be consequences.
content: A decade ago, I wrote a book with the subtitle “The New Isolationism and the Coming Global Disorder.” I’ve been wrong about a thing or two (or three) over the years. I wish I had been wrong about this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: An Ultrasound Experiment Tackles a Giant Problem in Brain Medicine
description: The effects of drugs that treat Alzheimer’s, cancer and other illnesses are often limited by the blood-brain barrier. A small study suggests a way forward.
content: There is a problem with the recently approved Alzheimer’s drug, Aduhelm. It can remove some of the amyloid that forms brain plaques that are hallmarks of the disease. But most of the drug is wasted because it hits an obstacle, the blood-brain barrier, that protects the brain from toxins and infections but also prevents many drugs from entering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Former Minister Arrested After Standoff at Poland’s Presidential Palace
description: The incident escalated a campaign by the ousted Law and Justice party to resist the transfer of power after it lost its parliamentary majority in October.
content: Poland’s bumpy transition to a new government hit dramatic turbulence on Wednesday when a prominent hard-line minister in the former right-wing administration declared himself a “political prisoner” and announced he was going on a hunger strike to protest his arrest following conviction for abuse of power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The Tech That Needs Fixing in 2024, and What Got Fixed Last Year
description: The best tech, from universal power charging to foldable phones, solved practical problems. But the worst tech, including self-driving cars and cryptocurrency, put us in harm’s way.
content: Tech companies would like us to believe that their products tell a story about progress. Faster phones! Better cameras! Brighter screens! Yet despite all the improvements, there are pieces of tech that have been flawed for years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Did We Learn From a Year in Live Shows?
description: Concerts paused during the height of the pandemic, and returned at full power in 2023. Our pop music editor saw a lot of them.
content: No one on the New York Times pop music staff attends more live shows than Caryn Ganz, the pop music editor. On this week’s Popcast, she reflects on the first full post-pandemic year of live performances, with stadium and arena tours finally back at full strength.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Democrats Set Ambitious Spending Plan for State Legislative Races
description: After trying to catch up to Republicans for a decade, Democrats are stressing the importance of down-ballot positions on big political issues.
content: The Democratic Party’s organization that focuses on state legislative races is planning its largest campaign budget ever as it seeks to flip five chambers in three critical swing states, as well as defend three recently earned majorities, according to a memo of the group’s 2024 strategy obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Trump Promotes False Birther Conspiracy About Nikki Haley
description: False and racist attempts to sow doubt about a political rival’s eligibility for the nation’s highest office are part of the former president’s playbook.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has reached back into his brand of nativism to accuse a political opponent of color — this time, Nikki Haley — of not being a real American eligible for the presidency as he defends his own eligibility for the ballot under the Constitution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Hunter Biden Appears on Capitol Hill as House G.O.P. Votes for Contempt
description: Two House committees voted to approve a contempt of Congress citation for President Biden’s son after he made a surprise appearance on Capitol Hill, prompting bitter partisan fighting.
content: Two House committees voted on Wednesday along party lines to hold Hunter Biden, the president’s son, in contempt of Congress, hours after he surprised Republicans by appearing unannounced on Capitol Hill, prompting a partisan free-for-all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: What to Watch at the Haley-DeSantis Debate and the Trump Town Hall
description: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis will debate on CNN on Wednesday night, at the same time that Donald Trump is holding a Fox News town hall.
content: Only two Republicans, Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, will take the CNN debate stage at Drake University in Des Moines on Wednesday night for the final televised clash before the Iowa caucuses next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Tracey Tully
title: Menendez Lashed Out in the Senate. Now, He’s Fighting Back in Court.
description: Lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez filed a dismissal motion on Wednesday, offering a first glimpse into the New Jersey Democrat’s defense strategy.
content: Lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat charged with accepting cash and gold bribes, asked a judge on Wednesday to dismiss the indictment, saying overzealous prosecutors were criminalizing normal legislative activity and flouting constitutional protections afforded to members of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Mortgage Rates and Inflation Could Draw Attention to the Fed This Election
description: The Federal Reserve is poised to cut rates in 2024 while moving away from balance sheet shrinking. Yet a key event looms in the backdrop: the election.
content: This year is set to be a big one for Federal Reserve officials: They are expecting to cut interest rates several times as inflation comes down steadily, giving them a chance to dial back a two-year-long effort to cool the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: E. Leo Milonas, 87, a Lion and a Defender of New York Courts, Dies
description: As an administrator of courts in New York State and New York City, he championed judicial independence and defendants’ rights and was unafraid to speak out.
content: E. Leo Milonas, a resolute jurist who administered New York courts for a quarter-century and was known to rise to defend his fellow judges in public disputes, in one case sparring with Mayor Edward I. Koch, died on Jan. 2 at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: U.S. Carbon Emissions Fell in 2023 as Coal Use Tumbled to New Lows
description: The drop was big, but emissions will need to fall three times as fast for the rest of the decade if the country wants to meet its climate goals.
content: America’s greenhouse gas emissions fell 1.9 percent in 2023, in large part because the burning of coal to produce electricity plummeted to its lowest level in half a century, according to estimates published on Wednesday by the Rhodium Group, a nonpartisan research firm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Conservatives Revolt Anew Over Johnson Deal to Avert Shutdown
description: A dozen hard-line Republicans ground business to a halt in protest of the deal Speaker Mike Johnson struck with Democrats to avert a shutdown, leaving the funding package in limbo.
content: Conservatives thrust the House back into chaos on Wednesday, grinding business to a halt in protest of the spending deal Speaker Mike Johnson struck with Democrats to avert a government shutdown and leaving the funding package in limbo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro and Katherine Rosman
title: Secret Synagogue Tunnel Sets Off Altercation That Leads to 9 Arrests
description: Videos showed a tumultuous scene as young Hasidic men clashed with the police in the global headquarters of the Chabad-Lubavitcher movement in Brooklyn.
content: A decades-old fight about the direction of one of New York’s most prominent Hasidic Jewish groups tipped into chaos this week, when one faction clashed with the police over a tunnel that had secretly been built to the movement’s main synagogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: ‘Gas-Station Heroin’ Sold as Dietary Supplement Alarms Health Officials
description: Tianeptine, found at convenience stores, at smoke shops and online, can mimic an opioid. It is among a growing class of substances that are difficult to control.
content: The young father headed across the parking lot to join the other parents meeting their children’s new preschool teachers. After a few steps, he began sweating and twitching. As the sky reeled, he staggered back to the car, desperate to lie down in the back seat and breathe, hidden by tinted windows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Democrats Question Semiconductor Program’s Ties to Wall St.
description: Two progressive lawmakers warned the Biden administration against creating a revolving door between industry and government as it prepares to hand out $39 billion in grants.
content: Two Democratic lawmakers on Tuesday expressed concerns about ex-Wall Street financiers overseeing the Commerce Department’s distribution of $39 billion in grants to the semiconductor industry, saying the staffing raised questions about the creation and abuse of a revolving door between government and industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catrin Einhorn
title: One Way to Stay Safe in a Storm: Take Care Around Trees
description: Roots are more likely to give way when soil is saturated and winds are high. Here’s how to protect yourself and your home.
content: Like homes, cars and electricity lines, trees provide vital services. But they can also be dangerous, even deadly, in storms or when they are not cared for properly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liset Cruz
title: Nearly 2,000 Migrants Are Evacuated From Brooklyn Tent Shelter Before Storm
description: The shelter housed migrant families with children. City officials said they were moved to a high school nearby to spend the night.
content: New York City evacuated on Tuesday about 500 families with children — nearly 2,000 people in total — from a massive tent shelter set up on a desolate former airplane runway in southern Brooklyn ahead of heavy rains and wind expected to hit the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith and Jenna Russell
title: Prolific Challenger of Trump’s Ballot Eligibility Faces Federal Tax Charges
description: John Anthony Castro, the long-shot G.O.P. candidate behind many suits to disqualify Donald J. Trump, is accused of preparing false tax returns.
content: A long-shot Republican presidential candidate who has repeatedly, and so far unsuccessfully, tried to have Donald J. Trump thrown off the primary ballot was arrested this week on federal charges of preparing false tax returns for clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Shaer
title: Why Are American Drivers So Deadly?
description: After decades of declining fatality rates, dangerous driving has surged again.
content: In the summer of 1999, a few years after graduating from medical school, Deborah Kuhls moved from New York to Maryland, where she had been accepted as a surgical fellow at the R Adams Cowley Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore. Founded by a pioneer in emergency medicine, Shock Trauma is one of the busiest critical-care facilities in the country — in an average year, doctors there see approximately 8,000 patients, many of them close to death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan, Wesley Parnell and Ana Ley
title: Subway Train Derails in Brooklyn in 2nd Such Episode in a Week
description: The train, a Manhattan-bound F, went off the tracks in Coney Island on Wednesday afternoon. No injuries were reported.
content: A subway train derailed in Brooklyn on Wednesday afternoon, police and fire officials said. It was the second derailment incident in New York City’s mass-transit system in less than a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and John Eligon
title: At World Court, Israel to Confront Accusations of Genocide
description: Israel has categorically rejected the allegations being brought this week in the International Court of Justice by South Africa.
content: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, will begin hearings this week in a case brought by South Africa that accuses Israel of committing genocide in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 5, Episode 9 Recap: Cowboy Hitler
description: “The most I ever felt, I felt for that woman,” Roy confesses. It’s safe to wager Dot never felt the same.
content: “You Hitler at the Reichstag or Hitler in the bunker?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Regulators Approve New Type of Bitcoin Fund, in Boon for Crypto Industry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized financial firms to offer a Bitcoin investment product that some hope will accelerate adoption of the technology.
content: Federal regulators on Wednesday approved a new financial product that tracks the price of Bitcoin, a landmark moment for the cryptocurrency industry that proponents hope will increase investment in the technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: A ‘National and Global Maelstrom’ Is Pulling Us Under
description: Trump has ushered in the age of the “great misalignment.”
content: The coming election will be held at a time of insoluble cultural and racial conflict; a two-tier economy, one growing, the other stagnant; a time of inequality and economic immobility; a divided electorate based on educational attainment — taken together, a toxic combination pushing the country into two belligerent camps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Women’s Hockey Team Breaks Into the New York Market
description: P.W.H.L. New York plays tonight at Belmont Park and is one of six teams in the new women’s league.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about New York’s newest professional sports team, which is scheduled to play its first game at UBS Arena at Belmont Park on Long Island tonight. We’ll also check on the state of two states, New York and New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: Trump Has Suggested Violence Could Erupt if Court Cases Do Not Go His Way
description: In recent days, former President Donald J. Trump has warned of “bedlam in this country” and “big, big trouble” if courts were to rule against him.
content: Twice in recent days former President Donald J. Trump has openly suggested that there could be violence should the Supreme Court rule against him in his ballot eligibility dispute, or if the federal case against him for plotting to overturn the 2020 election proceeds, warning of “big, big trouble” and “bedlam in this country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: U.S. Diet Panel Adds Another Researcher With Alcohol Industry Ties
description: After dropping two Harvard experts who had received industry support, the National Academies turned to a colleague with a similar background.
content: Shortly after dropping two Harvard scientists with financial conflicts of interest, the national organization assembling a committee to assess the evidence about drinking and health has chosen four new panelists, among them another Harvard professor who also has financial ties to the alcohol industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner and Claire Moses
title: 1 Killed in Avalanche at Lake Tahoe Ski Resort
description: The avalanche, at Palisades Tahoe in Olympic Valley, Calif., drew a large emergency response. One other person was treated for a minor injury, the authorities said.
content: One person was killed and one other person was injured in an avalanche at a popular ski resort in Lake Tahoe in California on Wednesday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy, Katherine Miller and Vishakha Darbha
title: Setting the Stage for Iowa: ‘Trump Will Probably Be Over 50 Percent’
description: Two Opinion editors help raise the caucus curtain.
content: The Republican caucuses in Iowa are just five days away, marking the official start of the 2024 presidential election season. To kick-start Opinion Audio’s coverage, Patrick Healy, the deputy editor of Times Opinion, and the Opinion editor Katherine Miller get together to discuss their expectations for Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis, where they think the G.O.P. is headed and Donald Trump’s continued dominance. Stay tuned for more on-the-ground analysis from “The Opinions” in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: How to Watch the Republican Debate Taking Place in Iowa
description: Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley will face off on CNN at 9 p.m. Eastern time tonight.
content: Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis will meet on Wednesday night in Des Moines for the last Republican presidential debate before the Iowa caucuses on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Effort to Revamp I.R.S. Faces Challenges Despite Funding Infusion
description: The Office of the National Taxpayer Advocate lamented that the tax collection agency, which now faces budget cuts in Congress, is still struggling to answer the telephones.
content: A multibillion-dollar federal effort to modernize the Internal Revenue Service has not yet solved the agency’s struggles to answer customers’ calls, ameliorate identity theft or process amended tax returns, the agency’s watchdog wrote on Wednesday in a report to Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Blocked Toilets Close Eton, Boarding School for Britain’s Elite Sons
description: Flooding and a sewer backup have delayed the start of the new term. Classes at the school, which has educated princes and prime ministers, will move online.
content: The first prime minister of Britain, Robert Walpole, went to Eton College. So did Boris Johnson and David Cameron and more than a dozen others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Indian American Leaders in Iowa Say They Feel Abandoned by Nikki Haley
description: Ms. Haley, the daughter of Indian immigrants, has a natural constituency in Iowa’s Indian American voters, but leaders say she has not reached out.
content: With less than a week to go before the Iowa caucuses, leaders with some of the largest and most active Indian and South Asian American associations in the state say Nikki Haley has missed a major opportunity to run up her margins against her opponents: Engaging Indian American voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: In Newark, 16-Year-Olds Win the Right to Vote in School Board Races
description: New Jersey’s largest city will allow 16- and 17-year-olds to vote. Supporters hope it’s the start of a statewide and national movement.
content: Residents as young as 16 have been granted the right to vote in school board elections in Newark, New Jersey’s largest city, beginning in April, after the City Council unanimously approved an ordinance Wednesday lowering the voting age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: The Biggest Ape That Ever Lived Was Not Too Big to Fail
description: Fossil teeth reveal Gigantopithecus was doomed by a changing environment and an inflexible diet.
content: Standing nearly as tall as a basketball hoop and weighing as much as a grizzly bear, Gigantopithecus blacki was the greatest ape to ever live. For more than a million years during the Pleistocene, Gigantopithecus roamed southern China. But by the time ancient humans reached the region, Gigantopithecus had vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alon Davidi
title: The Agony and Determination of Sderot
description: The mayor of an Israeli town attacked by Hamas on Oct. 7 describes the devastation, the will to recover and the source of its resilience.
content: Until the morning of Oct. 7, the town of Sderot in southern Israel was a parable of hope and success. Less than a mile from the Gaza border, it emerged a few years after the 1948 Arab-Israeli war as a haven for Jewish refugees fleeing antisemitic persecution — from North Africa, Kurdish lands, Ethiopia and the former Soviet Union. I am a second-generation Israeli; my parents found refuge in Israel from Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: For Jews, an Unanswered ‘Prayer for the French Republic’
description: In Joshua Harmon’s play about the legacies of antisemitism, a Parisian family must decide when it’s time to get out.
content: Such is the sadness of our world that plays about antisemitism, however historical, cannot help but be prescient. Take “Prayer for the French Republic,” Joshua Harmon’s sprawling family drama about the Salomons, Jews who have “been in France more than a thousand years,” as one of them puts it, still sounding provisional. With violent incidents on the rise, and a fascistic, Nazi-adjacent party gaining in the polls, should they finally seek safety elsewhere?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Missing Profits May Be a Problem for the Green Transition
description: The inability to generate acceptable returns is impeding the switch to renewable energy.
content: In October, the International Energy Agency issued a brief flare of optimism when it suggested that global carbon emissions from fossil fuels may already have peaked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Hunter Biden’s Capitol Visit Surprised Republicans, and His Father’s Advisers
description: The White House is trying to keep its distance as the president’s son deploys an aggressive new strategy.
content: When Hunter Biden interrupted a House Oversight Committee vote over holding him in contempt of Congress on Wednesday, Republican lawmakers were not the only ones caught off guard. President Biden’s advisers were surprised to see him there, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: How to Watch Trump’s Town Hall on Fox News
description: Fox News will host the event from Iowa starting at 9 p.m. Eastern time tonight.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will join the Fox anchors Bret Baier and Martha MacCallum at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Wednesday for a live town-hall event. It will be broadcast on Fox News and can be streamed at Foxnews.com with a cable login.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: To Run the British Museum, You’ll Get $275,000 and a Host of Problems
description: The museum is seeking a new leader to manage the fallout from recent thefts and demands to return contested items. Applicants have two weeks to apply.
content: Wanted: Someone to restore trust in one of the world’s most visited museums after an embarrassing scandal, handle restitution claims and raise $1.27 billion for a major refurbishment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Madrid
title: Why Biden Must Collide With the Democratic Party on Immigration
description: Brokering a deal could help the president shore up the nontraditional alliance that got him elected four years ago.
content: The negotiations on Ukraine funding and stricter border protections have exposed a growing rift between President Biden and his own party. Republican hard-liners have demanded a bill that mirrors policies advanced during the Trump administration, especially ones related to asylum seekers, increased border security and the mandate that companies institute the E-Verify employment eligibility system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Unveils App Store for Custom Chatbots
description: People who subscribe to OpenAI’s ChatGPT Plus service will be able to browse the new store for tailored chatbots that perform different tasks.
content: OpenAI said on Wednesday that it was opening an app store for people to share customized versions of its popular chatbot, ChatGPT, as the artificial intelligence company works to expand the reach of its flagship technology and turn it into a moneymaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Katz and Toni Monkovic
title: WordleBot’s New Preferred Opening Word: Trace
description: We’re adding words to the bot’s dictionary, and wiping the slate to make way for a new starter.
content: In our recent analysis of 515 million Wordle games played over a year, we noted that a few changes would soon be coming to WordleBot’s dictionary. As of today, those changes are now live — including a new opening word in both regular and hard mode.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Recaps Donald Trump’s Latest Day in Court
description: Jimmy Fallon joked that Trump has so many trials that “at this point, the courtroom sketch artist doesn’t even draw him — she just traces the grooves in her desk.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Donovan
title: A Match Made in Heaven: Pimento Cheese and Flaky Pie Crust
description: It used to feel impossible to improve on something as tasty as pimento cheese. That was before I started collaborating with other chefs.
content: In a world in which we hope to be seduced and moved by food, mayonnaise just sits there, daring us all to love it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: At an Emotional Governors Awards, Painful Losses and Heartfelt Tributes
description: The academy honored Mel Brooks, Angela Bassett, the recently widowed editor Carol Littleton and Sundance’s Michelle Satter, whose son died in a shooting.
content: Despite the chockablock ballroom full of Hollywood’s best and brightest, a jovial emcee in the comedian John Mulaney and honorees the audience seemed thrilled to celebrate, a pall of sadness was cast over the Governors Awards — an event created 14 years ago by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to shorten the Oscar telecast by relegating the honorary Oscars to its own untelevised confab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Adan Canto, Actor in ‘The Cleaning Lady’ and ‘X-Men,’ Dies at 42
description: In a career spanning more than a decade, Mr. Canto played a range of roles, including a control-obsessed criminal, a poised politician and a fiery comic book hero.
content: Adan Canto, the Mexican actor known for his roles in TV series such as “The Cleaning Lady” and “Designated Survivor” as well as for playing Sunspot in the film “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” died on Monday. He was 42.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: G.O.P. Opens Mayorkas Impeachment Push With No Evidence of High Crimes
description: The first House hearing on impeaching the homeland security secretary featured Republicans accusing him of willfully failing to enforce immigration laws and an expert who testified there was no case.
content: House Republicans on Wednesday kicked off formal impeachment hearings against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, accusing him of willfully failing to enforce immigration laws even as leading constitutional experts said there was no basis to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Erin Nolan
title: 5 Takeaways From Hochul’s State of the State Address
description: The governor of New York described a state that was struggling with crime, the cost of living and a mental health crisis as she laid out her goals for the year.
content: In her third State of the State address, Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday laid out her vision for the coming legislative session and described objectives that often were more of a reflection of her moderate roots than the state’s recent progressive slant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Norma Barzman, Blacklisted Screenwriter, Dies at 103
description: After she and her husband, a fellow writer, saw work in Hollywood dry up during the Red Scare, they continued their careers in self-exile overseas.
content: Norma Barzman, a screenwriter who moved to Europe in the late 1940s rather than be subject to the congressional investigations and professional ostracism that overtook her industry for a decade, died on Dec. 17 at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 103 and widely considered to be one of the last surviving victims of the Hollywood blacklist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: S.E.C. Social Media Hack That Sent Bitcoin Soaring Prompts Investigation
description: Legal experts said investigators would look into how the security breach occurred and whether anyone tried to profit from it.
content: The hack of a social media account used by the Securities and Exchange Commission is prompting both internal and external investigations into how the security breach occurred and whether anyone tried to profit from it, said the commission and several legal experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: For This Reporter, the War in Ukraine Is Also Personal
description: Yaroslav Trofimov grew up in Kyiv. “Our Enemies Will Vanish” records his experience as a journalist for The Wall Street Journal assigned to cover the war.
content: “Kyiv was still a city at peace,” Yaroslav Trofimov writes about the afternoon of Feb. 23, 2022, the day before Russian forces invaded Ukraine. The sun was shining, the bars were full; he saw no scenes of panic buying at the shops or snaking lines at the A.T.M.s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Iowa Nice vs. New Hampshire Ornery: A Tale of Spurned Democrats
description: In Iowa, Democrats politely accepted President Biden’s decision to push them back on the presidential nominating calendar. In New Hampshire, they’re fighting it with live-free-or-die stubbornness.
content: When President Biden shook up his party’s presidential nominating calendar, Democrats in the two states that were bounced from the front of the line reacted in far different ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Trump Won’t Give Closing Argument at Fraud Trial After Judge Sets Limits
description: The former president’s lawyer said he could not abide by limitations set by the judge in the civil fraud case. “I will not hesitate to cut him off,” wrote Justice Arthur F. Engoron.
content: Donald J. Trump backed down from delivering his own closing argument in his civil fraud trial after refusing to abide by a judge’s restrictions — including that he not give “a campaign speech” — in the latest clash between Mr. Trump’s political aims and American legal norms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Christopher F. Schuetze
title: As U.S. Support for Ukraine Falters, Europe Splits on Filling the Gap
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is likely to find strong backing on a trip to the Baltic States, but other nations are increasingly wary.
content: In Estonia, a four-story banner that combines the flags of Ukraine and Estonia hangs over a main square in the capital, Tallinn. In Latvia, Foreign Minister Krisjanis Karins is calling for allies to “ramp up military support to Ukraine without delay.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Christopher Nolan Continues Momentum with Directors Guild Nomination
description: Greta Gerwig is also nominated for “Barbie.” Most but not all of the nominees for this prize often go on to Oscar nominations.
content: The Directors Guild of America announced the nominations for its feature-film award on Wednesday, lending further momentum to nominee Christopher Nolan (“Oppenheimer”), who won the Golden Globe for directing on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Way to Improve How Children Read
description: Readers respond to a proposal by Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York. Also: Donald Trump’s immunity claim; the Biden age issue; hope when facing death.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: What to Know About the Chaos in Ecuador
description: Violence erupted across the South American country this week after a notorious gang leader disappeared from prison. The president has declared a state of emergency.
content: Violence erupted across Ecuador this week after a well-known gang leader disappeared from prison. Explosions, looting, gunfire and burning vehicles were reported, and there were uprisings in several prisons. In the largest city, Guayaquil, gunmen stormed a TV studio during a live broadcast on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elyssa Dudley, Tina Antolini, Lynn Levy and Daniel Ramirez
title: Our Predictions for 2024
description: Stiff drinks, molten chocolate and logging off for good.
content: Every January, we ask our most trend-obsessed colleagues to make predictions about the year ahead. Here are their best guesses about what 2024 will hold for fashion, food, technology and culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: More Than 20 Million People Have Signed Up for Obamacare Plans, Blowing by Record
description: The Biden administration said that a record number of Americans had signed up for coverage in 2024 through the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces, a sign of the law’s durability.
content: More than 20 million people have signed up for plans on the Affordable Care Act’s marketplaces during the annual open enrollment period, far surpassing last year’s record of more than 16 million enrollments, the Biden administration announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Donald Trump’s immunity claim in court.
content: At a hearing in Washington yesterday, Donald Trump appeared in front of an appeals court panel to argue that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election because they arose from actions he took as president. The three judges on the panel seemed unconvinced, suggesting that they are unlikely to rule in the former president’s favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Can Iowa Hold a Proper Caucus for Once?
description: The closely-watched contest has been a hot mess for more than a decade.
content: The most-watched early presidential contest in America has been a hot mess for more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Iowa’s Governor Bet on DeSantis. Voters Aren’t Thrilled.
description: Kim Reynolds remains popular among Republicans in her state, but she drew grumblings from Trump supporters by throwing her weight behind his opponent.
content: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa broke with tradition and with former President Donald J. Trump in November when she endorsed Ron DeSantis for president in her state’s first-in-the-nation caucuses, a move that surprised political observers and Iowa voters alike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Thomas Fuller and Edward Wong
title: After Red Sea Barrage by Houthis, U.S. and Allies Weigh Retaliation
description: American officials and their allies warned that there would be consequences for the Houthis, the Iranian-backed armed group that has disrupted shipping in the Red Sea.
content: The United States and its allies are weighing how to stop attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea after American and British officials said on Wednesday that their navies had intercepted one of the largest barrages yet of drones and missiles fired from an area controlled by the Houthis, an Iranian-backed group in Yemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Alice Parker, Composer Who Heard Music in Poetry, Dies at 98
description: A master of American choral music, she wrote arrangements of hymns, folk songs and spirituals used in concert halls and churches countrywide.
content: Alice Parker, whose arrangements of hymns, folk songs, and spirituals were used in concert halls and churches across America, and who composed 11 song cycles and four operas, died on Dec. 24 at her home in Hawley, Mass. She was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Maps
description: Treasure maps. Road Maps. Fanciful Maps. What are your favorite memories with these geographic tools?
content: Are you fascinated by maps? Have you ever made one yourself?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: All-Female City Council Marks a ‘Turning Point’ for a Twin City
description: For the first time in St. Paul, Minn., all seven City Council members are women. They also make up the youngest and most racially diverse council in the city’s history.
content: There was a moment last summer when Nelsie Yang realized that she and six other women were on the verge of making history in St. Paul, Minn. The group of City Council candidates was knocking on doors to share their joint campaign message, one that could transform the makeup of the city’s governing body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Put a Rink on It
description: From 100 stories high in New York to the balmy shores of Florida, Instagrammable ice skating rinks are popping up all over America.
content: This winter, for the first time in recent history, it’s possible to ice skate underneath the Brooklyn Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: Tell Us the Little Things You Do for Love
description: What small acts of affection help keep you and your partner connected?
content: Valentine’s Day is just around the corner and, sure, plenty of people dismiss it as a commercialized scam. But for others, the holiday is a welcome occasion to pause and remind your partner what they mean to you (or, at the very least, to eat a little chocolate).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Meets With Abbas to Talk About Gaza’s Future
description: The U.S. secretary of state spoke with Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, about the role the authority might play after Israel’s war with Hamas.
content: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, met on Wednesday with Mahmoud Abbas, the leader of the Palestinian Authority, to discuss Israel’s war against Hamas in Gaza and the role that the authority might play there when the conflict ebbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 10, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 10, 2024.
content: An entry in the Dateline feature on Sunday about the places from which Times journalists are reporting misstated the results of the presidential election in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The incumbent president, Felix Tshisekedi, was declared the winner; the country did not elect a new president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: kinesiology
description: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word kinesiology has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 6 in “Uncoordinated? You Can Still Be an Athlete” by Jenny Marder:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: One of Trump’s Oldest Tactics in Business and Politics: I’m Rubber. You’re Glue.
description: Whenever Donald Trump is accused of something, he responds by accusing his opponent of that exact thing. The idea is less to argue that Mr. Trump is clean than to suggest that everyone else is dirty.
content: Days before the Iowa caucuses, former President Donald J. Trump is appearing twice in court this week — on Tuesday in Washington and Thursday in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Rabin
title: How the War With Hamas Has Damaged Israel’s Tech Firms and Economy
description: Israel’s technology sector, a key part of the economy, has been jolted by worker shortages and funding fears, which could drive a wider slowdown in 2024.
content: At 6:45 a.m. on Oct. 7, Jack Bigio, the founder of the technology company UBQ Materials, talked to his chief operating officer, who said terrorists were on his kibbutz. Other employees texted that they were hiding in safe rooms, and one said her husband had been shot in the stomach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: The EGOT Winner Behind Sondheim’s Signature Sound
description: For Jonathan Tunick, an early love of “Tubby the Tuba” led to a career as an orchestrator. He talks about his Sondheim partnership, and creating a sound that “can hint at unspoken secrets.”
content: To understand the role of the Broadway orchestrator, seek out the composer Stephen Sondheim’s piano demo for the song “Losing My Mind” from the musical “Follies” and then compare it to the version on the original cast recording. The demo’s tone is wistful and resigned, with a touch of the whiskey bar about it. In the finished version, the song sounds transformed: Ascending notes on the strings, interjections from the brass and crashing cymbals build to a powerful climax, evoking the heartache and inner turmoil contained in the lyric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise, Cade Metz and David McCabe
title: Microsoft Debates What to Do With A.I. Lab in China
description: Amid U.S.-China tensions, the company has faced questions over whether operating an advanced research lab in Beijing is politically tenable.
content: When Microsoft opened an advanced research lab in Beijing in 1998, it was a time of optimism about technology and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Allegations Against Prosecutors Bolster Trump’s Criticism of Georgia Case
description: A defendant in the case has accused the district attorney in charge of it and a special prosecutor she hired of being romantic partners, saying the case should be dismissed.
content: It seemed an unusual choice when Fani T. Willis, the district attorney in Fulton County, Ga., turned to a suburban defense lawyer to oversee what seemed the biggest task of her career: building an election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: Was This Man’s Weakness Related to Recent Oral Surgery?
description: His doctor had darker suspicions.
content: It was early morning when the woman crept into the living room, where her 82-year-old partner was sleeping. He didn’t usually sleep in his recliner but was in and out of bed so many times with diarrhea two nights earlier that she was relieved when he decided to sleep in his favorite chair. His eyes opened as she started to close the door. “I can’t get out of the chair,” he said quietly. His feet were on the floor, but, he told her, he didn’t have the strength to rise or even move. This was a man who, in the 21 years she’d known and loved him, was still only when he was asleep. Now, with his arms hanging limply beside him, his face pale behind his constant New Mexico tan, he looked weaker and sicker than she had ever seen him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Ken Bensinger
title: Appeals Court Finds DeSantis Violated Prosecutor’s First Amendment Rights
description: The ruling deals a blow to the Florida governor on a decision he uses to bolsters his conservative credentials.
content: Dealing a blow to Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a federal court of appeals on Wednesday ruled that he had violated First Amendment protections when he suspended a progressive state prosecutor for political gain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.3 Million Homes in Florida, Georgia and Delaware
description: A coastal house in Santa Rosa Beach, an antique rowhouse in Savannah and a two-bedroom condominium in Wilmington.
content: This house is near 30A, a 24-mile span of road along the Gulf Coast that connects Santa Rosa Beach to other popular beach communities, including Rosemary Beach, Seaside and Seacrest. It is less than a mile from a public access point to a beach with white sand and gentle surf, and a 10-minute drive from a Publix supermarket and several casual seafood restaurants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Amanda Holpuch and Judson Jones
title: After a Day of Unsettled Weather, Here’s the Forecast
description: While conditions were calmer in the Southeast U.S., rain was expected in Maine, and snow in parts of the West. The New York region was facing brutal winds. Flood warnings remained in effect along the East Coast.
content: Much of the United States was continuing to grapple on Wednesday with a mixed bag of unsettled weather — snow, rain, strong winds, flooding and freezing temperatures — that had upended daily life for millions of people from coast to coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Christie’s Exit Is Jolted as Hot Mic Picks Up His Unvarnished View of Rivals
description: As he bowed out of the presidential race, Mr. Christie was heard mocking Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis. His departure leaves the field without its most vocal Trump critic.
content: Former Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey suspended his presidential campaign on Wednesday, but he undermined his effort to stop Donald J. Trump when he sweepingly dismissed his Republican rivals during a hot-mic moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: SAG Award Nominations 2024: It’s a ‘Barbenheimer’ Rematch
description: The summer blockbusters each garnered four nominations. Notable snubs included Leonardo DiCaprio of “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
content: Box office behemoths “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” led this year’s nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards, which were announced Wednesday morning. Each film picked up four nominations, including ones for the guild’s top ensemble prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: These Wedding Vendors Get Paid to Work on Their Phones
description: Brides and grooms are hiring content creators to film, edit footage and produce Instagram and TikTok posts with music, transitions and behind-the-scenes moments.
content: While searching on TikTok for ideas for her April 22, 2023 wedding, Mila Tweel came across several videos of former brides discussing what they would have done differently. Many regretted not hiring someone to capture behind-the-scene videos and photos of their wedding day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Inside the Mayor’s Closet
description: Ten suits, 19 ties, crisp white shirts and pin collars — a 30-day snapshot of Mayor Eric Adams’s style.
content: When Mayor Eric Adams emerges from his official limousine, so too does a glimpse of poplin, chambray and gabardine: some of the New York City mayor’s collection of crisp shirts, tailored suits and custom neckties often travels with him, swinging from a rack in the back seat of his black Chevrolet Suburban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Trump’s Argument for Immunity in 2024 Is the Opposite of His Stance in 2021
description: During his second impeachment trial, the former president argued that criminal prosecution was a more appropriate way to seek accountability since he had left office.
content: When former President Donald J. Trump appeared before an appeals court in Washington this week to claim he was immune from prosecution for his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, one of his lawyers argued that he should not face criminal charges because the Senate had failed to convict him of similar offenses at an impeachment trial three years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Christie Caught on Hot Mic Disparaging Haley and DeSantis
description: “She’s going to get smoked, and you and I both know it,” Mr. Christie seems to have said, presumably referring to Nikki Haley.
content: As speculation about his future in the presidential race swirled, Chris Christie was caught on a hot mic on his campaign’s livestream in a conversation before his scheduled event in Windham, N.H., discussing his Republican rivals in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark and Ana Swanson
title: The Next Front in the U.S.-China Battle Over Chips
description: A U.S.-born chip technology called RISC-V has become critical to China’s ambitions. Washington is debating whether and how to limit the technology.
content: NASA has chosen the technology to help it land future spacecraft on unmapped planets. Meta uses the technology for artificial intelligence. Chinese engineers have turned to it to encrypt data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: The Fight Against Houthi Rebels
description: Preview: Also, violence in Ecuador.
content: The U.S. and its allies are trying to figure out how to stop attacks by Houthi rebels based in Yemen against commercial ships in the Red Sea. This comes after American and British forces said yesterday that they intercepted one of the largest barrages of missiles and drones yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: N.Y.P.D. Will Not Face Budget Cuts After All, Adams Says
description: The mayor said that not only would there be no police hiring freeze, but that 600 recruits were on the way. Libraries still face budget reductions.
content: Mayor Eric Adams said on Wednesday that the city had restored funding to the New York Police Department and would add 600 recruits in April, a reversal of the dire warning he gave in November that there would be a hiring freeze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: The Saxophone Master Shabaka Hutchings Is on a Fresh Journey: Flutes
description: The British musician is an artist in residence at Winter Jazzfest in New York this week, playing an instrument group that he first picked up in 2019.
content: As Shabaka Hutchings led a concert tribute to Pharoah Sanders in early December, he returned to a familiar equation: funneling gallons of air through his tenor saxophone, transforming it into a corrosive stream of sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Big Bitcoin Tease
description: A bogus social media post declaring that the S.E.C. had approved an E.T.F. tied to the cryptocurrency caused prices to whipsaw. A real decision could come as soon as Wednesday.
content: The famously volatile price of Bitcoin briefly experienced more whiplash than usual on Tuesday, after a post on an official S.E.C. social media account said that the agency had approved long-awaited investment products tied to the cryptocurrency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Alex Stern, Eric Krupke, Jessica Cheung, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Trump’s Case for Total Immunity
description: Why the former president believes he should be immune from prosecution, and whether judges are likely to rule in his favor.
content: Donald Trump has consistently argued that as a former president, he is immune from being charged with a crime for things he did while he was in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Adler-Bell
title: The Shadow War to Determine the Next Trump Administration
description: The king hasn’t returned from exile, but he is already inspiring acrimony and disarray among his courtiers.
content: A disturbing sense of inevitability hangs over the Iowa caucuses on Monday. Donald Trump, with a 34-point lead in the polls, is the all but certain Republican nominee. And despite his legal troubles, Mr. Trump leads Joe Biden in several general election polls in swing states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: U.S. Hit by Record Number of High-Cost Disasters in 2023
description: There were 28 storms, wildfires or other disasters that each cost at least one billion dollars in damages, a sign of the growing economic burden of climate change.
content: The United States experienced 28 disasters last year that each cost at least one billion dollars, the highest number on record and the latest measure of the growing toll of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Does My Sister Want to Be Paid for Being the Executor of My Mother’s Will?
description: Months after the bulk of their mother’s estate was divided and paid, a reader’s sister is seeking to keep a remaining balance of $150,000 as payment for her work as an executor.
content: My mother passed away in 2021. She left her estate in equal shares to my sister, my brother and me. My siblings were named coexecutors of her will. It was relatively easy to sort out her house and belongings and to distribute the money. My sister insisted on handling everything: “I’ve got it,” she would say when we offered to help. Most of the funds were distributed soon after my mother’s death. But there remains a balance of $150,000. When my brother asked my sister to distribute it, she sent a long email saying she deserves to be paid for her work. My brother and I are surprised, sad and angry: The will doesn’t say anything about paying executors. My sister was an ample beneficiary, and her work was finished 18 months ago. If she wanted to be paid for what I view as an act of love, she should have brought it up at the beginning. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hwaida Saad
title: Hamas says hostages won’t go home alive as long as Israeli forces remain in Gaza.
description: Netanyahu faces growing pressure to get the more than 100 hostages still held in Gaza home safely.
content: Israeli hostages held in the Gaza Strip “will not be returned alive” unless Israeli forces leave, a Hamas spokesman said on Wednesday, highlighting the predicament facing the Israeli government: It has vowed to free the hostages, and to pursue the war and defeat Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: In Florida, New School Laws Have an Unintended Consequence: Bureaucracy
description: Under recent rules, some students can’t take a vision test or get a Band-Aid without permission slips. And it’s up to schools to hunt them down.
content: Got a cut and need a Band-Aid? Want to be called Will instead of William? Or get your vision checked?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: A Dinner Party So Easy You Don’t Even Need Recipes
description: A little technique is the key to this three-course meal from David Tanis, of a bright citrus salad, comforting cauliflower cheese and a pistachio chocolate bark.
content: People often tell me they simply can’t cook without a recipe. But often you don’t really need one: You need a technique, a method.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Al Shabab Terrorist Group Captures U.N. Helicopter in Somalia
description: Somali officials said the helicopter was carrying nine passengers, one of whom was killed. The Horn of Africa nation is now grappling with how to rescue hostages from a group known for mistreating them.
content: A United Nations helicopter carrying nine passengers was captured in Somalia on Wednesday by the terrorist group Al Shabab after making an emergency landing because of technical difficulties in an area controlled by the group, three senior Somali officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Botox Destroyed What I Liked About My Face
description: I didn’t realize my wonky eyebrows were so dear to me until they were gone.
content: I tried Botox for the first time two years ago. I was rapidly approaching my 40th birthday, and like so many other people, I spent the early Covid years staring at my increasingly pallid and wrinkled visage through daily video calls. That I succumbed to the expensive allure of cosmetic injectables as a result of this scrutiny was both banal and mildly embarrassing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Cottrell
title: Papua New Guinea Orders Military to Restore Order as Unrest Rocks Capital
description: Angry protests started after hundreds of police officers and other public servants appeared to walk off their jobs over a wage dispute.
content: The government of Papua New Guinea on Wednesday ordered the military to restore order in the capital, Port Moresby, after a dispute over the wages of police officers and other public servants led to angry protests and unrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: December Was One of the Warmest on Record in California
description: The state’s weather in 2023 wasn’t especially toasty overall, but December was an exception.
content: Despite all the holiday songs about sun-baked beaches and snowless Christmas celebrations, December in California actually tends to be cool and damp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Our Five-Star, Thai-Inspired Chicken Meatball Soup With Over 14,000 Reviews
description: Is there anything cuter or more fun to eat than a meatball? Snuggled into a sandwich, slid onto skewers or perched on top of spaghetti, meatballs are inherently playful — more than their close cousin meatloaf, which is far too square to roll off the table and out of the door.
content: Is there anything cuter or more fun to eat than a meatball? Snuggled into a sandwich, slid onto skewers or perched on top of spaghetti, meatballs are inherently playful — more than their close cousin meatloaf, which is far too square to roll off the table and out of the door.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Kuzma
title: Your Workout Routine Isn’t Complete Without Strength Training
description: Aerobic exercise is hugely beneficial for health. But research increasingly shows you also need some resistance training. Here’s how to work it in.
content: Anh Bui’s main focus as a physical therapist is to treat and prevent running injuries. Her most common prescription for patients? Lifting weights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Virginia Fisherman Is Linked to Three 1980s Killings, Police Say
description: Alan W. Wilmer Sr., who died in 2017, was responsible for the homicides, the authorities said, including a double killing that was among a series known as the Colonial Parkway murders.
content: A Virginia fisherman who died in 2017 was responsible for the killings of three people in two separate cases in the southeastern part of the state that sat unsolved for more than 30 years, the police announced this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: Tina Fey on ‘Mean Girls’ Then and Now
description: With a new version of Regina George and the Plastics headed to theaters, she reflects on how different generations have reacted over the years.
content: Tina Fey spent the summers of 2002 and 2003 hunched over an old desk in the mildewy back room of a Fire Island rental home. Fueled by coffee and Entenmann’s chocolate-covered doughnuts, Fey, at the time the head writer for “Saturday Night Live,” cracked the script that became “Mean Girls” on her laptop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joumana Khatib
title: Writing Is Doomed to Fail. That’s Why Hisham Matar Loves It.
description: Matar won a Pulitzer Prize for his memoir, “The Return,” mourning his homeland and his father. In his new novel, he turns to the untranslatability of exile — and friendship.
content: Talk to any friends of the writer Hisham Matar, and he has many, and soon they’ll bring up one of his more notorious pastimes: Have you ever seen how he looks at art?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Knife Attacker Hoped to End South Korean’s Presidential Bid, Police Say
description: The suspect had planned the attack last week on the country’s opposition leader for months, the police said, and had written an eight-page manifesto.
content: The man who stabbed the main opposition leader of South Korea in the neck last week wanted to kill him so that he would never become president, the police said, in an alarming escalation of the country’s political polarization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Natural Gas Played Role in Fort Worth Hotel Explosion, Officials Say
description: A fire official said that the authorities had yet to determine the specific cause but that there was nothing to indicate any foul play.
content: Officials in Texas have yet to determine exactly what caused an explosion at a hotel in downtown Fort Worth that injured 21 people, but believe natural gas was involved, Jim Davis, the city’s fire chief, said at a news conference Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson, Liset Cruz and Wesley Parnell
title: A School Sheltered Migrants in a Storm. The Hate Calls Poured In.
description: Migrant families were evacuated to the auditorium of James Madison High School. The school went remote the next day, and families and elected officials protested.
content: An angry backlash erupted at a Brooklyn high school on Wednesday, after New York City officials housed about 500 migrant families in an auditorium there overnight because of heavy rains and fierce winds at their shelter site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Scariest Part About the Boeing 737 Max 9 Blowout
description: What I heard wasn’t necessarily reassuring.
content: You should worry that a crying baby will be in the seat next to you. You should worry that snow in Chicago will snarl air traffic. But you should never, ever have to worry that a plug in the side of your plane — a hidden weak spot — will suddenly blow out at 16,000 feet. That is what happened to Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 shortly after takeoff from Portland, Ore., on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italian Town Hitches Its Wagon to Plants That Bloom (Even in Winter)
description: Lakefront Verbania in Italy’s Piedmont seeks to attract flower lovers with its mild climate, spectacular gardens and wild nature.
content: Even as the group of flower aficionados flitted around a high-ceilinged room admiring just-clipped camellias with fanciful names like “Pink Lassie” and “Paradise Petite,” single petals floated lazily to the paneled wood floor, forming colorful mounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: East Coast Faces Flooding After Day of Rain
description: Millions of people from the Mid-Atlantic to New England faced the risk of flooding as rivers rose after a day of rain.
content: The heaviest rain from a widespread storm that drenched the eastern United States appeared to have ended in much of the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast by Wednesday morning, but meteorologists said the risk of flooding had just begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Climate Change Is Driving a Sharp Drop in Snow Levels, Study Finds
description: Parts of the Northern Hemisphere are warming enough that their prospects of future snow are rapidly declining.
content: Changing snow patterns have far-reaching consequences, from water shortages to shuttered ski resorts. A new study confirms that human-caused climate change has affected snow patterns across the Northern Hemisphere, including clear declines of snowpack in at least 31 individual river basins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Chris Christie Ended His Presidential Bid
description: Also, the U.S. weighs retaliation after Red Sea attacks. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Chris Christie, the former New Jersey governor who positioned himself as the Republican candidate for president most willing to attack Donald Trump, dropped out of the race today after months of campaigning failed to secure him more than a sliver of support in polls. In the end, Christie’s attacks against Trump, whom he called unfit for office, appear to have distanced him from the party’s base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Oligarch’s Aide Tells Court How Sotheby’s Expertise Had Role in Fraud
description: An adviser to Dmitry Rybolovlev said the opinions of an expert from the auction house were used to persuade him to buy overpriced art. Sotheby’s said it was not part of any scheme.
content: An adviser to a Russian billionaire asserted in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday that he and his boss had been tricked by a Swiss art dealer into wildly overpaying for works of art and that a Sotheby’s expert’s opinions played a role in persuading them to pay the inflated prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Pat McAfee’s On-Air Slams of ESPN Executive Show a Network Power Shift
description: For decades, the biggest star at ESPN was ESPN. That’s changing as it transitions from cable dominance to a much less certain streaming future.
content: As it morphs from a television company into a streaming company, ESPN is undergoing rapid transformation. But if the extraordinary events of the past week are any indication, the transformation of its corporate culture is just as seismic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: A Fellow Cop Let My Father-In-Law Slide on a Breathalyzer Test. What to Do?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to proceed in the wake of moral and civic disgrace.
content: My father-in-law hides his drinking and denies it, but when we visit, we see him sneak out to the car and drink vodka from the trunk many times a day. We live close by and see my in-laws quite often; hence we also see him drinking frequently, even though my husband has tried hard to get him to stop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris
title: We Are in a Big Covid Wave. But Just How Big?
description: Wastewater data has become perhaps the best metric to track the spread of the virus in the U.S., but it’s an imperfect tool.
content: The curves on some Covid graphs are looking quite steep, again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: An Immigration Shift
description: Leading Democrats once supported immigration enforcement measures. Today, much of the party is uncomfortable doing so.
content: Since Donald Trump first ran for president in 2016, the Democratic Party has changed its own approach to immigration. Not long ago, leading Democrats supported immigration enforcement measures like tough border security and deportations. Today, much of the party is uncomfortable doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Setback for Heirs in Long-Running Nazi Art Restitution Case
description: A U.S. Court of Appeals decision allows a Spanish museum to keep a Pissarro in a dispute that has lasted nearly two decades.
content: The heirs of a woman who was forced to surrender a painting to the Nazis were dealt a blow on Tuesday in a decades-long legal feud between them and the Spanish museum that now owns the work, when a California appellate court ruled that the museum should retain ownership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Hochul Warns of Flooding Risks and Lingering Power Outages
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said the most significant problems caused by the storm were likely to persist after it moved on.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York cautioned residents on Tuesday evening about two major storm-related problems that were likely to linger after the system moved on: widespread power outages and the risk of flooding in certain parts of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Use of A.D.H.D. Drugs Surged During Pandemic, Study Finds
description: Social media influencers and online marketing may have played a role, experts said.
content: Prescriptions for drugs used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder surged during the coronavirus pandemic, particularly among women and patients ages 20 to 39, according to new research compiled by scholars affiliated with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Food Assistance for Mothers and Children Faces Funding Shortfall
description: The Agriculture Department has warned that millions of eligible pregnant and postpartum women and their children could risk missing out on nutrition assistance if Congress does not increase funding.
content: For the first time in decades, many states could begin turning away eligible applicants from an assistance program that provides low-income women and their children critical access to food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leigh-Ann Jackson
title: With ‘Echo,’ Alaqua Cox Smashes Boundaries, and Bad Guys’ Faces
description: The actress almost didn’t audition for the Marvel superhero role that now has her playing the lead of a new Disney+ series. Thank goodness for peer pressure.
content: “I thought in the back of my head, There’s no way I’m going to get this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: How Do You Keep a Tidy House? It Helps to Have a Tidy Mouse.
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, January 11, 2023.
content: “Lo and behold, I got a video of the mouse. Tidying up for me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Women With Depression During or After Pregnancy Face Greater Suicide Risk, Even Years Later
description: Two studies concluded that depression that began in pregnancy or soon after could have troubling implications for as long as 18 years.
content: Women who experience depression during pregnancy or in the year after giving birth have a greater risk of suicide and attempted suicide — risks that persist for years, two new studies report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: U.N. Expert Will Investigate Reports of Sex Crimes by Hamas, Israel Says
description: The official accepted Israel’s invitation and is expected to go there soon, the foreign ministry said. Hamas has denied that its fighters committed sex crimes during the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: The United Nations’ special representative on sexual violence in conflict has accepted Israel’s invitation to investigate allegations of sex crimes committed by Hamas on Oct. 7, a spokesman for Israel’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Amazon Cuts Hundreds of Jobs at Studios and Twitch
description: The layoffs add to a growing number of cuts in the tech industry this past year.
content: Amazon is laying off hundreds of employees at its studio division as well as its subsidiary Twitch to reduce costs, the latest in a wave of new job cuts hitting the tech industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: What to Know After Severe Storms Hit Vast Areas of the U.S.
description: Flooding, flight delays and power outages remain widespread after hazardous weather ranged across much of the nation.
content: Strong winds and heavy rain left hundreds of thousands of utility customers in the eastern United States without power on Wednesday. Roads and buildings across a wide region were flooded and battered by the storm, with some rivers and streams still rising.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: An Oatmeal Cookie for Raisin Haters
description: A puddle of blueberry maple jam is stuffed inside these tender, gently spiced treats.
content: It may come as a shock to legions of chocolate chip devotees, but there’s a small but passionate faction of cookie lovers who prefer oatmeal raisin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: How a TV Show Forced Britain’s Devastating Post Office Scandal Into the Light
description: After years of delays, victims of one of the U.K.’s worst miscarriages of justice are finally being exonerated — thanks to a TV drama.
content: More than 700 people convicted of a crime they didn’t commit. At least four suicides. A woman sent to jail while pregnant. Bankruptcies. Marriages broken, lives ruined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Amalija Knavs, Mother of Former First Lady Melania Trump, Dies at 78
description: A patternmaker from Slovenia, she and her husband became naturalized U.S. citizens with the help of their daughter and then a focal point in the debate around Donald Trump’s immigration policies.
content: Amalija Knavs, a former Slovenian factory worker who became a United States citizen with help from one of her daughters, Melania Trump, has died. She was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Guards Beat and Waterboarded Prisoners in New York, Lawsuits Say
description: A guard placed a cloth over a prisoner’s face and poured water over him, creating a sensation that mimics drowning, according to court papers.
content: Two prisoners in upstate New York say they were brutally beaten by guards and taken to a different facility to be waterboarded — a method of torture once used by C.I.A. interrogators on terrorism suspects, according to newly filed lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: Then and Now: Revisiting the Sopranos’ New Jersey 25 Years Later
description: On the anniversary of the show’s premiere, its creator and location manager reflect on some of its iconic settings and why they were chosen.
content: As much as it was a show about Italian American mobsters, “The Sopranos” was a show about New Jersey. From scenes of domestic life in a North Caldwell McMansion to after-hours debauchery at a strip club in Lodi, the show captured a snapshot of the Garden State in the late 1990s and 2000s, beguiling viewers with its regional authenticity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian J. Rivera, Patrick Healy and Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: ‘Why Would Trump Win This Election When He Lost the Last One?’
description: Eight Republican voters from Iowa offer their thoughts on the upcoming caucuses.
content: Eight Republican voters from Iowa offer their thoughts on the upcoming caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Levi
title: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Don’t Hug Me I’m Scared’ and More
description: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying.
content: I’m an editor who works on features for The Times’s print edition. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Marisa Schwartz Taylor
title: A Closer Look at What the U.S. Lets You See of Its War Court at Guantánamo Bay
description: The Times explores the place where photography is allowed at Guantánamo's secretive war court — and explains what you can and cannot see.
content: The Times explores the place where photography is allowed at Guantánamo's secretive war court — and explains what you can and cannot see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helmuth Rosales and Anjali Singhvi
title: A Look at the Panel That Ripped Open an Alaska Airlines Jet
description: A diagram of the door plug shows the locations of critical bolts that federal investigators said may have been missing or improperly installed.
content: A diagram of the door plug shows the locations of critical bolts that federal investigators said may have been missing or improperly installed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Menendez Motion to Dismiss
description: Lawyers for Sen. Robert Menendez filed a motion on Wednesday arguing that the bribery case against him should be dismissed.
content: Lawyers for Sen. Robert Menendez filed a motion on Wednesday arguing that the bribery case against him should be dismissed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Hanley, James Surdam and Marisa Schwartz Taylor
title: Inside Guantánamo Bay
description: Take a look inside the detention and court operations with Carol Rosenberg, the New York Times Guantanamo Bay correspondent.
content: Take a look inside the detention and court operations with Carol Rosenberg, the New York Times Guantanamo Bay correspondent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: ‘We Live in Constant Fear’: Violence Erupts Across Ecuador
description: Chaos has consumed Ecuador after gang leaders escaped prisons and armed men commandeered a live TV broadcast.
content: Chaos has consumed Ecuador after gang leaders escaped prisons and armed men commandeered a live TV broadcast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Severe Storms Rip Roofs Off of Homes in the Southeast
description: Strong winds and likely tornadoes destroyed several buildings in the Southeast.
content: Strong winds and likely tornadoes destroyed several buildings in the Southeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Storyful and The Associated Press
title: Severe Storms Sweep Across the Eastern U.S.
description: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings. In parts of the South, apparent tornadoes tore through homes.
content: Heavy rain and powerful winds stretched up the East Coast, flooding streets and buildings. In parts of the South, apparent tornadoes tore through homes.
source.name: The New York Times
